indicators.justification:
Environmental data have been provided through the Statistical Institute of Jamaica (STATIN) (1) including information about rainfall, sunshine, pollution incidents, greenhouse gas, protected forest area, sea level, water composition, land use, fishery and water consumption. The data are available using a dataZoa account.

Source
(1) https://statinja.gov.jm/Environmentdata.aspx

responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
Nationally published data includes detailed information on greenhouse gas emissions and targets reported to the UNFCCC.
Data contains detailed information on sources of greenhouse gas emissions.
Emissions data includes, or site where emissions data is made available links to, details of land use effects on emissions.
The dataset contains unique identifiers for greenhouse gas emissions that allow easy assessment across inventories, reduction commitments, and sources.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

indicators.justification:
A bio-diversity assessment has been done, although the document is dated in 2009 by the Jamaica Clearing-House Mechanism (1). The National Environment and Planning Agency is the government body with responsibility for the protection of endangered species and ecosystems (2). A National Strategy and Action Plan for Biological Diversity exists and includes 2013 data (3).

Sources
(1) https://jamaicachm.org.jm/CHM/data-sharing/
(2) https://www.nepa.gov.jm/environmental-conservation
(3) https://www.cbd.int/doc/world/jm/jm-nbsap-v2-en.pdf

evidence.title: National Strategy and Action Plan on Biological Diversity in Jamaica

indicators.justification:
The STATIN has a process of collecting and publishing information about vital statistics. The data have been found online (1) and data are available in open format on the STATIN's website (1). the data collection forms are also available online (2). 
Source
(1) https://statinja.gov.jm/Demo_SocialStats/newbirthdeathmarriage.aspx
(2) https://www.rgd.gov.jm/images/PDF_FILE/RGD_Updated_Form/flow_diagram_dealing_with_bedside_registration.pdf

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
The data includes information on data limitations, specifically on the completeness of vital statistics in different provinces, counties, or regions of the country.
Cause of death is standardized to the International Classification of Causes of Death (ICD) or a related, fully interoperable standard.
Mortality information includes data about age, sex and/or gender, geographic location, and cause of death.
Birth information includes data about sex and/or assigned gender of child, gestational age, and birth weight.
Birth information includes data about live-birth order and interval between last and previous live births to mother.
Birth information includes data about place of occurrence, place of usual residence of mother, and month of occurrence.
Birth information includes data about place of registration and month of registration.
Birth information includes data about age, educational attainment, and ethnic and/or national group of mother.
Birth information includes data about age of father and place of usual residence.
Birth information includes data about site of delivery, attendant at birth, and month in which prenatal care began.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.

indicators.justification:
Jamaica has taken steps to strengthen its Health Informatics and has a Strategic Business Plan (1). The digitization of health information is in process (2). The Ministry of Health and Wellness provides a state of the health system reports (3).

indicators.justification:
Jamaica has a vaccination tracker and its vaccination plan has been made public. Vaccination data can be found primarily on the Ministry of Health and Wellness' website and other sources (1) and (2).

Sources
(1) https://jamcovid19.moh.gov.jm/vaccination.html
(2) https://jis.gov.jm/booking-vaccination-appointment-online-is-easy/

responses.response_text: Data is available, but not as a result of government action.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?

The data includes information about the geographic distribution of vaccinations.
The data includes information about the age of the people who have been vaccinated.
The data includes information about the sex and/or gender of the people who have been vaccinated.
The data includes information about the disability status of the people who have been vaccinated.
The data includes information about membership in a marginalized population among the people who have been vaccinated.
The data includes information about vaccination for residents of long-term care facilities.
The data includes information about vaccination for residents of prisons and jails.

indicators.justification:
The Ministry of Finance and the Public Service publishes annual and supplementary budget estimates (1). A tax expenditure statement is provided (2). Revenue estimates and financial statements are also provided (3).

Source
(1) https://mof.gov.jm/budgets/annual-and-supplementary-estimates.html
(2) https://mof.gov.jm/revenues/tes.html
(3) https://mof.gov.jm/budgets/revenue-estimates.html

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

indicators.justification:
A report on campaign financing by the Electoral Commission of Jamaica indicates that this matter is closely monitored and that the information will be published. Declaration forms exist (1) including declarations of financial and non-financial donations (2) and (3). Details about donors are required. Evidence was found in the media that the information can be sourced (4).

Sources
(1) https://ecj.com.jm/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Form5-Declaration-of-Contributor.pdf
(2) https://ecj.com.jm/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Form22-Parliamentary-Return-of-Election-Expenses.pdf
(3) https://ecj.com.jm/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/RegulatingElectionCampaignFinancing.pdf
(4) https://www.jamaicaobserver.com/front-page/corporate-cash-splash-private-sector-entities-donate-millions-to-jlp-pnp_202235&template=JamaicaDecidesArticle

evidence.title: Report by Electoral Commission of Jamaica

indicators.justification:
Access to Information requests data have been provided in Jamaica although may not be openly formatted. The Ministry of Finance and the Public Service provides a report online on requests from January 2004 to September 2016 (1). The Office of the Prime Minister publishes responses to information requests (2). The Ministry of Local Government provides persons who wish to access information with a user guide (3). Facilitation of access to information requests exists in Jamaica.

Source
(1) https://mof.gov.jm/documents/documents-publications/document-centre/file/1297-ati-requests-jan-2004-sept-2016.html
(2) https://opm.gov.jm/category/access-to-information-responses-and-responses-to-questions/
(3) https://www.localgovjamaica.gov.jm/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/ati-userguide.pdf

Data is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity.
Dataset is available free of charge.

Data is timely and updated.

indicators.justification:
The Public Procurement Act (2015) (1) and the eTendering system (2) are main procurement instruments of the Government of Jamaica. The tendering process is transparent (3) and the award of contracts has been published (4).

Sources
(1) https://japarliament.gov.jm/attachments/article/341/The%20Public%20Procurement%20Act,%202015.pdf
(2) https://www.gojep.gov.jm/epps/home.do

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
Procurement related to goods and services is included.
Procurement related to public works is included.
The planning phase is covered.
The tender stage is covered.
The award stage is covered.
The contract implementation stage is covered.

The data contains names and unique identifiers for companies awarded contracts.

The data contains, or can be linked to, information on spending against the contract.

The data is published according to one or more relevant data standards.
The data contains links to accessible tender, award, or contract documentation
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.

Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.

responses.response_text: The data assessed covers, or is representative of the data available for, almost all public procurement.

indicators.justification:
Several initiatives have been held in Jamaica to support the reuse of data including information sessions about digital technologies (1) and uploading data (2). The use of data by both private and public sectors is encouraged (3).

Source
(1) https://moey.gov.jm/registration-g-suite-training-%E2%80%93-cohort-4
(2) https://mof.gov.jm/mof-media/media-centre/press/2334-taj-holds-access-to-third-party-information-sessions-out-west.html
(3) https://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/first-ever-jamaica-survey-of-establishments-launched_175731

responses.response_text: There is isolated evidence of government supporting and encouraging data reuse.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of a government strategy to support and encourage data reuse?
There is evidence of government efforts to support open government data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support big data reuse in a general sense.
There is evidence of government efforts to support private sector or NGO data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support crowdsourced data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse from various data topics.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by civil society organizations.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by media.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by scholars and academic institutions.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by the private sector.
Government support for data reuse involves data challenges.
Government support for data reuse involves hackathons.
Government support for data reuse involves communication and community building efforts.
Government support for data reuse involves running information sessions on how to use particular datasets, or how to reuse government data in general.
Government support for data reuse involves the release of funding schemes

responses.response_text: Support assessed is at national level.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the support assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
Jamaica has launched an open data portal (1) and is in the process of obtaining approval for this Open Data Policy. The island was one of the first Caribbean countries that conducted an Open Data Readiness Assessment (2). The Ministry of Science and Technology leads an open data initiative in the country. Minister Fayval Williams hailed the Data Protection bill (3).

Sources
(1) (1) https://data.gov.jm/search/field_tags/portal-guide-386
(2) http://radiojamaicanewsonline.com/business/jamaica-gets-high-marks-for-open-data-readiness
(3) https://www.mset.gov.jm/2020/05/19/press-release-data-protection-bill-seeks-to-protect-personal-data/

responses.response_text: There is evidence of an active government-led open government data initiative.
responses.subquestion_text: Has there been any form of government-led open government data initiative during the study period?
There is a government team in place supporting open data activities.
There is an allocated budget for open data activities.
There is a well-maintained open data portal.
There is guidance and support for government publication of open data.
Senior political leaders back the open data initiative.

responses.response_text: The open data initiative covers only a limited part of the national government, but there are similar initiatives for many other parts of government.
responses.subquestion_text: How widely does this, or similar, open data initiatives apply?

indicators.justification:
The Statistical Institute of Jamaica leads and has the capability to manage data (1). As such data management has been centralized in one agency. Nonetheless, the Ministry of Local Government has an access to information process in place (2) that has to be facilitated by effective data management. Information is disclosed in the public interest (3).

Source
(1) https://statinja.gov.jm/
(2) https://www.localgovjamaica.gov.jm/resources/?category=12
(3) https://www.localgovjamaica.gov.jm/public-interest/

responses.response_text: There is evidence of sustained and institutionalized capability to manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent do city, regional, and local governments have the capability to effectively manage data?
There is evidence of local governments having open data initiatives.
There is evidence of local governments having current open data policies in place.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place to provide a comprehensive framework for data sharing.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place for consistent data management and publication.
There is evidence of local governments providing training to civil servants on data literacy and skills.
There is evidence of local governments providing support for data reuse.

responses.response_text: The examples given represent common practice: many cities or regions have comparable capacity to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread are local capacities to effectively manage data?

indicators.justification:
The Management Institute for National Development has been mandated to train public servants (1) and customized courses such as about spatial data have been done (2).
Data training has been made available to key public servants. STATIN the key agency with responsibility for data matters conduct in-house and local training (3).

Sources
(1) https://mind.edu.jm/public-sector-learning-framework-pslf/
(2) https://jis.gov.jm/nsdmb-committed-to-gis-awareness-and-training/
(3) https://statinja.gov.jm/pdf/Final%20Annual%20Report%202018-19%20(combined%20doc%20with%20cover)%20updated%20for%20website.pdf

responses.response_text: There is some evidence of government  supporting civil servants training on data matters, as part of a planned and sustainable strategy.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of  government´s actions to train civil servants on data matters?
Training delivered covers data frameworks and governance topics.
Training delivered to public servants covers topics on data gathering.
Training delivered covers data analysis, visualisations and storytelling techniques.
Training delivered covers specific technical topics for data centred roles.
Training on data addresses non-technical public servants.
Training on data is focused on specific positions already working with data.
Training is planned by an established training team, department, or agency.
Public servants receive a certification when taking a training so there is a formal recognition as a professional development.

responses.response_text: The training assessed is representative of the kind of training that can be found for all, or most, agencies or ministries.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread, in terms of agencies and ministries, are the trainings assessed for this question?

responses.response_text: Assessed trainings involve national public servants.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread, in terms of jurisdictions, are trainings assessed for this question?

indicators.justification: Partial consistency exists between datasets such as a name search, however broad interoperability across multiple datasets was not evident.

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

responses.response_text: There is partial consistency; several categories of identifiers are consistent across multiple datasets or whole identification systems are consistent across at least two datasets.
responses.subquestion_text: To what degree do the datasets associated with this theme use consistent identifiers and identification systems for elements that appear in more than one dataset?

indicators.justification:
The Companies Act (2004) (1) and its Amendments cover the publication of companies in Jamaica. An online search can be done to find beneficial ownership information as a search feature allows for entry of company name and information can be found that identifies a company's Directors (2). The Companies Act at Section 337 makes provision for the publication of the information by the Registrar in the Gazette (1).

Source
(1) https://www.orcjamaica.com/uploads/Companies%20Act%202004%20(Bookmark%20Version).pdf
(2) https://www.orcjamaica.com/Services.aspx

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in non-binding policy or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
Definitions comprehensively cover ownership.
Definitions cover control.
Rules or processes exist to protect certain natural persons who are beneficial owners from having their data published.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The rules/guidance require beneficial ownership data to be collected in a central register or database.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: They cover the majority of limited companies in the country.
responses.subquestion_text: How widely do these laws, regulations, policies, or guidance apply?

indicators.justification:
A specific framework that addresses the access of persons with disabilities was not found. The Disabilities Act (2014) addresses matters of persons with disabilities in Jamaica and at Sections 24 and 25 such persons are not to be subject to discrimination (1).

Source
(1) http://admin.jcpdja.com/upload/339_TheDisabilitiesAct.pdf

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?

responses.response_text: There is a broader framework which can be presumed to apply to data.
responses.subquestion_text: Where does this requirement exist?
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The data management and publication of data for Jamaica are well managed by the Statistical Institute of Jamaica (STATIN). The publication and management are governed by the Statistics Act (1). The STATIN follows international standards and has detailed methodologies about the data management process and information about the metadata. Please refer to the Jamaica Data Classification Structure and National Accounts Standards (2).

Sources
(1) https://moj.gov.jm/sites/default/files/laws/Statistics%20Act.pdf
(2) https://statinja.gov.jm/Methodology.aspx#METH

responses.response_text: A framework exists but lacks full force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
There are minimum standards for metadata when government data is catalogued or published.
There is a standardised process for publishing and updating published government data.
There are technical standards, including common data models, codelists, and identifiers for management and publication of government data.
There are clearly documented quality control processes for government data.
There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

responses.response_text: The data management approaches assessed generally apply across the whole public sector.
responses.subquestion_text: How broadly is good data management practice established?

indicators.justification:
The Records and Information Management Policy (1) and Government Data Sharing Policy (2) are guiding documents about data sharing in Jamaica. The open data portal has provided a mechanism for data sharing (3). The Government of Jamaica views the open portal portal as a 'Transformation Initiative'.

Sources
(1) https://www.jard.gov.jm/sites/default/files/public/policy-documents/rim_policy_0.pdf
(2) https://nlj.gov.jm/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Government.Data_.Sharing.Policy.pdf
(3) https://jis.gov.jm/open-data-portal-launched-june-24/

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework covers data sharing within government.
The framework covers how government should share data with other sectors.
The framework covers data sharing from other sectors to government.
The framework covers data sharing within the private sector.
The framework explicitly focuses on artificial intelligence uses of data.

responses.response_text: The framework assessed covers all government agencies, and many themes.
responses.subquestion_text: How broad is the coverage of legal or policy frameworks for data sharing for the public good?
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The Jamaica Data Protection Act (2020) covers all matters relating to the protection of personal data and enforcement of the use of such data (1). Data protection policies are being implemented in the private sector in keeping with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) (2018) (2). The GDPR is a European Law that applies to companies once they offer services to persons in Europe.

Sources
(1) https://japarliament.gov.jm/attachments/article/339/The%20Data%20Protection%20Act,%202020.pdf
(2) https://www.jngroup.com/data-protection/

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent.
The framework provides data subjects with rights to access and correct data about themselves.
The framework sets out clear responsibilities for data holders.
The framework provides rights of redress
The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.
Frameworks explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.
The framework addresses algorithmic decision making.
Exceptions to the usual data protection framework have been made as part of the country's COVID-19 response.

responses.response_text: The framework applies widely across all sectors (including public and private sector).
responses.subquestion_text: How broadly does this data protection framework apply?

responses.response_text: The framework assessed, or equivalent frameworks, apply across the whole country.
responses.subquestion_text: Does this framework apply across the whole country?

indicators.justification:
The Statistical Institute of Jamaica publishes data about the country in the national language, that is English. The matter of data quality is addressed by the STATIN through its methodology that has been published on its website (1).

Source
(1) https://statinja.gov.jm/Methodology.aspx#/intro

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
Where does this requirement exist?
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.

indicators.justification:
The Government of Jamaica has a final draft of the Open Data Policy (1). Jamaica was one of the first countries in the Caribbean to conduct an Open Data Readiness Assessment. The work of the Caribbean Open Institute has also helped to advance Open Data initiatives in the country.

Source
(1) Ministry of Science and Technology

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework establishes a common definition of open data.
The framework promotes open licensing without any restrictions beyond attribution and share-alike.
The framework requires to publish data in machine readable formats.
The rules/guidance requires the use of specific data standards.
The framework promotes training and capacity building among government officials.

responses.response_text: The relevant laws, policies and guidance assessed cover the majority of localities and government agencies.
responses.subquestion_text: How widely do these laws, regulations, policies or guidance apply?

indicators.justification:
The Financial and Administration and Audit Act and Amendments guide the publication of financial data (1) and (2). Annual budget reports are published on the Ministry of Finance and the Public Service, including information about public debt (3). A Chief Internal Auditor by law is appointed to verify all budget estimates.

Sources
(1) https://moj.gov.jm/sites/default/files/laws/The%20Financial%20Administration%20and%20Audit%20Act_0.pdf
(2) https://moj.gov.jm/sites/default/files/laws/The%20Financial%20Administration%20and%20Audit%20Act.pdf
(3) https://mof.gov.jm/documents/documents-publications/document-centre/category/193-public-debt-annual-reports.html

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
Summary reports must be provided as structured data.
Expenditure information at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification must be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require executive budget proposal information to be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require the approved or enacted budget to be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require in-year reports as structured data.
The rules/guidance require year-end reports as structured data.

The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification:
The Integrity Commission operates utilising certain laws and publish annual reports. Documents are utilised to collect income and asset declarations from senior public officials (1). Both the Integrity Commission Act (2017) (2) and The Corruption (Prevention) Act (3) govern data about interests and assets of senior public officers. According to the law an annual submission is required no later than three months after the end of the year.

Sources
(1) https://integrity.gov.jm/sites/default/files/Sample%20Statutory%20Declaration%20Form.pdf
(2) https://japarliament.gov.jm/attachments/article/341/The%20Integrity%20Commission%20Act,%202017%20No.%2026--.pdf
(3) https://moj.gov.jm/sites/default/files/laws/The%20Corruption%20Prevention%20Act.pdf

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

The framework requires collecting specific information on assets and liabilities.
The framework requires collecting specific information on in-kind and non-financial support.
The framework requires collecting information on significant changes in assets and liabilities.
The framework requires disclosure of income and assets held by a public official's spouse, family members, or other intimates.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The framework requires the publication of income and asset declarations.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification:
Lobbying does not seem to be a regulated practice in Jamaica. The matter has been raised in the media (1), (2) and (3). Nonetheless, the National Integrity Action group monitors activities in relating to corruption (4). 

Source
(1) https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/focus/20150913/pryce-right-full-disclosure-lobbyists
(2) https://jis.gov.jm/motion-regulation-lobby-groups-sent-house-committee/

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in non-binding policy or guidance.

The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of lobbyists, lobbying clients, lobbying activities, and public officials.
The framework requires the collection and publication of the identities of lobbyists, lobbyist clients, and public officials who engage with lobbyists.

The framework requires the collection and publication of information on how much money is spent on lobbying activities.

indicators.justification:
The Electoral Commission of Jamaica monitors matters relating to campaign financing. Documents are available on its website about the process of collecting information about campaign finance (1). The activities surrounding political campaign finance have been legislated and regulated (2). The Office of the Political Ombudsman has a role in relation to reporting about political campaigns including financing of such campaigns (3).

Source
(1) https://ecj.com.jm/resources/campaign-financing/
(2) https://ecj.com.jm/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Election-Campaign-Financing-Legislation-Regulations-Revised-July-2017.pdf

The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of campaigning activities of parties, candidates, and third parties.

responses.response_text: The framework does not require the disclosure, public or otherwise, of a donor's identity.

indicators.justification:
A framework does exists for consultations in the public domain. It is referred to as a Code of Consultation (1) and was developed by the Cabinet Office in 2005. The Code was developed under the Public Sector Reform Unit. As a guideline, the Code indicates the minimum requirements for effective consultations.

Source
(1) https://cabinet.gov.jm/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Consultation-Code-for-Public-Sector.pdf

evidence.title: Code for Consultation for the Public Sector

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.

The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.

indicators.justification:
The Access to Information Act (2002) and the Access to Information Unit carry out the function of freedom of information. All government agencies are required to publish the process to access information and this information is on the website, for example the Ministry of Finance and the Public Service's website (1). The Access to Information Unit is headed by a Director and has a public awareness campaign about the the right to information (2). An appeals process is in place and persons have a right to know why the information was not provided (3).

Source
(1) https://mof.gov.jm/access-to-information.html
(2) https://www.ati.gov.jm/sites/default/files/public/article-files/ati_booklet_layoutv5_19.03.18.pdf
(3) https://www.ati.gov.jm/page/access-information-appeal-tribunal

The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding the number of requests submitted and processed.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding material withheld and the reasons for withholding it.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding appeals to RTI determinations and their results.
The framework requires that information is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity.

indicators.justification:
The Companies Office of Jamaica (COJ) has information about companies online. Members of the local media have published information about companies although the source of the information cannot be verified (1). The COJ has also indicated that it will publish names of delinquent companies and directors (2)


Source
(1) https://www.jamaicaobserver.com/business-observer/feeling-conflicted-the-case-of-company-directors_200625
(2) https://jis.gov.jm/coj-publish-names-delinquent-companies-directors/

responses.response_text: One or more products/services exist, but they do not appear to make use of open datasets.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used in products/services?
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, government.
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, civil society
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, the private sector.
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, media.
There is evidence that at least one of the examples cited is making use of beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
Land data are being used for policy, rural and urban development and to address matters relating to climate change and housing policy (1), (2) and (3). Vision 2030 has identified land use as an aspect (4). Policies and plans have to consider land use (5) and a National Land Policy (1997) sets out considerations for land use and land resources (6). The National Strategy and Action Plan on Biological Diversity 2016-2021 includes land use planning (7).

Sources
(1) https://japarliament.gov.jm/attachments/article/2167/Draft%20National%20Housing%20Policy%20-%20July%2017%202019%20-%20For%20Tabling.pdf
(2) https://www.intechopen.com/books/sustainability-in-urban-planning-and-design/jamaican-universities-aiding-the-design-of-an-urban-public-space
(3) https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/news/20191222/david-salmon-unplanned-growth-solution-urban-sprawl-jamaica-pt-2
(4) https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/content/documents/1501jamaica.pdf

indicators.indicator_name: Use (L): Influencing policy for gender and inclusion
indicators.indicator_name_medium: Gender and inclusion uses of data
indicators.indicator_name_short: Gender and inclusion uses of data

responses.response_text: There are a number of cases of actors or entities using this kind of data to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use?
There is evidence of civil society organizations using data in this way.
There is evidence of media using data in this way.
There is evidence of academics using data in this way.
There is evidence of the private sector using data in this way.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
Is there evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts on land policy?

indicators.justification:
Information about political processes such as an Election Campaign is public (1). An Accountability Framework for Senior Executive Officers exists (2) and (3). The Framework includes management tools and guidelines and oversight functions. Non-government Organizations such as the National Integrity Action and Jamaicans for Justice monitor the accountability of government (4) and (5).

Source
(1) https://opo.gov.jm/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/2020-General-Election-Campaign-Review-Report.pdf
(2) https://cabinet.gov.jm/resources/jamaica-accountability-framework-032010/
(3) https://auditorgeneral.gov.jm/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/Jamaica-Accountability-Framework-ver-11-Final-March-2010.pdf
(4) https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/lead-stories/20200216/corruption-laws-must-bite-say-watchdogs-nia-jamp-blame-enforcement
(5) https://borgenproject.org/jamaicans-for-justice-protects-citizens/

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data for accountability purposes, though the source may not be open data.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
Evidence of the media's use of procurement information is online. Public procurement is a means to reduce wastage (1) improve transparency (2) and grow small businesses (3). Use of the data is evident to ascertain any breaches (4).

Sources
(1) https://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/public-procurement-commission-on-mission-to-reduce-waste_223502
(2) https://www.jamaicaobserver.com/business-observer/public-procurement_224335
(3) https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/business/20190724/msmes-get-special-access-government-contracts-clarke-table-procurement
(4) https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/lead-stories/20151127/ridiculous-1000-fine-business-leaders-civil-society-slam-paltry

responses.response_text: There is evidence of isolated uses or pilot projects.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
